Their breeding range extends across the Boreal Forest from northern and eastern Maine north to Newfoundland and west to British Columbia. In the West, they nest at higher elevations south into Mexico. Their numbers have declined by 80% since the 1970s and 1980s.

articles.title: Climate change driving migration in Accra — IOM
articles.summary: Climate change is driving migration patterns in Accra, forcing residents to relocate. The International Organisation for Migration (IOM) conducted a study in four communities in the Capital City of the country. It found that flooding, extreme heat, sea-level rise and unpredictable rainfall are the main climate hazards driving internal mobility in the city. It also revealed the loss of residential structures, permanent displacement and economic dislocation among women engaged in coastal livelihoods.

articles.title: Could corporate biodiversity efforts become a new front for greenwashing?
articles.author: Marta Nieto-Garcia
articles.summary: The global share of companies linked to both alleged greenwashing and biodiversity risks has doubled over the past five years. There is a rising awareness of nature-related risks and a growing pressure on companies to be more conscious of them.    .

articles.title: Homa Bay families brace for floods as critical control project stalls
articles.author: George Odiwuor
articles.summary: Rachel Ondago's village in Rachuonyo North, Homa Bay County is experiencing more frequent and unpredictable floods. Climate change is intensifying the water cycle and reducing the land's ability to absorb water. The government's dyke project that promised to end their suffering has stalled due to lack of funds.

articles.title: New AmeriCorps cohort joins Macomb's community initiatives
articles.author: The McDonough County Voice
articles.summary: AG Jackson joined AmeriCorps and Habitat for Humanity volunteers to build homes to mark one year since Tropical Storm Helene. Western Illinois University's Peace Corps Fellows and Amer iCorps Program were working with Habitat to build the homes.

articles.title: Animals adapting too slowly as climate change creates ecological trap
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: Case Western Reserve University's research on the gray tree frog found that climate change is making it difficult for the amphibian species to adapt to seasonal changes. The study underscores a subtle but critical challenge of climate change: species whose behaviour or physiology is tied to fixed environmental cues may be ill-equipped to respond when those cues become unreliable.

articles.title: One of Earth's most vital carbon sinks is faltering. Can we save it?
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: For decades, forest, grasslands and other land ecosystems have collectively absorbed up to a third of the carbon dioxide we emit each year. This climate buffer may be collapsing far sooner than anyone expected, as a result of climate change, according to a new report.

articles.title: New Zealand Seas Warming Fast, $180Bn Homes At Risk: Report
articles.author: Iwk Bureau
articles.summary: New Zealand's oceans are heating 34% faster than the global average, placing billions of dollars in homes and infrastructure at risk from rising seas, intensified marine heatwaves, and stronger storms. Ministry for the Environment and Stats NZ's latest three-yearly assessment, Our Marine Environment 2025, reveals alarming evidence of climate-driven transformations in the country's surrounding waters.

articles.title: Seas around New Zealand are warming 34% faster than the global average
articles.summary: The seas and oceans surrounding New Zealand are warming far faster than the global average. Many species, including the yellow-eyed penguin (hoiho) native to New Zealand, are struggling to adapt to the warmer, more acidic waters. Sea level rise is accelerating in many areas and 200,000 New Zealand homes are located in flood-prone zones.

articles.title: Experts at Thunder Bay conference say Canada's forests are drying out
articles.author: Rajpreet Sahota
articles.summary: Scientists are meeting in Thunder Bay this week at the Canadian Institute of Forestry's 117th annual conference. They are concerned about climate change changing forest moisture and fuel levels, the materials that feed wildfires. The conference continues until October 8, with sessions on Indigenous forest stewardship, biodiversity and strategies to build more resilient forest systems across Canada.

articles.title: Gardeners urged to leave out one common fruit for robins in October
articles.author: Alex Evans
articles.summary: Gardeners urged to leave out one common fruit for robins in October. Robins don't migrate south for winter, so gardeners need to provide them with food. Ark Wildlife recommends leaving out suet pellets, fat balls, fruits and berries and providing mealworms and calcium worms.

articles.title: Maui County Council to hear presentations from experts on climate change
articles.summary: Maui County Agriculture, Diversification, Environment and Public Transportation Committee will hear three presentations on climate change at 9 a.m. Thursday in the Council Chamber and online. The presenters will include Charles Fletcher, Tonya Graham, Darla Palmer-Ellingson of 360 Green Living and Jennifer VanderVeur, grants specialist for the state Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation Commission. The meeting will be livestreamed on Akakū Channel 53.

articles.title: Classic 1990s crime drama moves closer to getting sequel
articles.author: Cliff Pinckard
articles.summary: Warner Bros. is about to sell 'Heat 2' to Amazon MGM Studios. Michael Mann will write and direct the sequel. Jerry Bruckheimer, Scott Stuber and Nick Nesbitt will be producers. Leonardo DiCaprio is in talks to play Chris Shiherlis, Val Kilmer's role from the first film.

articles.title: Mayo to celebrate Climate Action Week with over 25 events
articles.summary: Mayo is celebrating Climate Action Week from October 9 to 20th. Events include GAA gear swaps, tree planting, bread making workshops, booklet launches, and celebrations of achievements such as O'Hora's Greenwall in Ballina. It is part of the nationwide initiative which is coordinated by An Taisce's climate action team on behalf of the Department of Climate.

articles.title: Report: Coastal, urban counties swelling
articles.author: Alan Wooten
articles.summary: Brunswick County along the Atlantic Ocean is North Carolina's fastest growing county since the outset of COVID-19. Since 2004, the county has doubled in size, going from 84,000 to 169,000. Currituck (15.8%), Pender (14.2%) and New Hanover (8.5%) were also significant gainers along the water. Hertford County lost nearly 2,400 residents to roughly 19,000, a drop of 11%.

More than 200,000 homes worth NZ$180 billion are at risk of coastal inundation and inland flooding.

articles.title: Over Half Of CA's Beaches To Vanish By 2100, Per Report
articles.author: Miranda Ceja
articles.summary: More than half of America's sandy shores will be lost by 2100 due to climate-driven sea level rise. 70 percent of that number is in California. Coastal communities are combating this change successfully with nature-based solutions even as federal climate support diminishes. The report features nine case studies from beaches across the country, including San Onofre State Beach.

articles.title: New Zealand coastal waters heat up 34% faster than global average

articles.title: ‘Degrading public trust': The exaggerated risks and ignored benefits of global warming
articles.summary: The national climate risk assessment was released a month ago. Roger Pielke Jr explains the exaggerated risks and ignored benefits of global warming in an interview with Sky News host Chris Kenny on American Enterprise Institute Senior Fellow Chris Kenny's show, Sky News Live.

articles.title: From Himalayas to oceans: How climate change is threatening migratory species
articles.summary: A new report from the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species (CMS) highlights the threats posed by climate change to migratory wildlife globally. The report highlights India's National Mission for Sustaining the Himalayan Ecosystem as a key response initiative. It calls for integrated landscape planning to maintain and restore connectivity essential for wide-ranging mammals adapting to climate stress.

articles.title: New Zealand's seas warming faster than global average

articles.title: ‘Implausible scenarios' makes climate risk assessment unreliable
articles.summary: Roger Pielke Jr. highlights the unrealistic data used in the national climate risk assessment. The report on the high end projects more than 12.5 billion people in 2100, which is impossible to believe. The assumption that the entire world would be transitioning to coal energy is also unrealistic.

articles.title: Florida county battered by 2024 hurricanes spends $125M on beach restoration
articles.author: The Daily Journal
articles.summary: The beaches along a swath of Florida's Gulf Coast were battered by three hurricanes last year, leading to a multimillion-dollar effort to repair them. The region's economic engine is the Indian Rocks Beach area of the Gulf Coast, which is the economic engine of the region.

articles.author: Anju Agnihotri Chaba
articles.summary: The first week of October brought unexpected and surplus rainfall to Punjab, Haryana and Chandigarh. The unseasonal showers have disrupted the crucial paddy harvesting season in Punjab and Hariesana. Fields remain waterlogged in several districts, forcing farmers to postpone harvesting.

articles.title: News4 First Alert Weather Extra: What contributes to cold winter blasts?
articles.summary: Zack Webster explains how decreasing daylight and insolation towards the North Pole lead to cold-air buildup and its steady migration southward. He explains how it's due to the decrease of daylight and the insolation near the North pole and its migration southwards.

articles.title: How Marine Heatwaves Are Weakening the Ocean's Ability to Fight Climate Change
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: Marine heatwaves are disrupting the ocean's 'biological carbon pump,' a critical system for combating climate change. The Gulf of Alaska experienced two major marine heatwaves over the past decade. Both caused significant disruptions to the base of the ocean food web. The changes had effects on how carbon moved through the ocean. Some types of plankton are more efficient at helping carbon sink, while others produce lighter waste.

articles.title: Evidence of climate problem before our very eyes but some still scoff at the science
articles.author: Steve Cardownie
articles.summary: Scottish First Minister, John Swinney, blamed the recent storm, Storm Amy, on climate change. Last year global temperatures hit new heights, with the average temporarily exceeding 1.5C above pre-industrial levels. Heatwaves have increased in frequency, are more severe and last longer, breaking records for hottest days and warmest months here in the UK. The Atlantic hurricane season produced multiple major hurricanes with extreme wind speeds and record rainfall causing floods in the Caribbean and American coastal states. US President Donald Trump has dismissed climate change as 'the greatest con job' or 'deception' ever inflicted on the world.

articles.title: Record-breaking 2024 Amazon fires drive unprecedented carbon emissions and ecosystem degradation
articles.summary: The Amazon rainforest has just experienced its most devastating forest fire season in over two decades. It triggered record-breaking carbon emissions and exposed the region's ecological fragility despite a slowing trend in deforestation. The study was done by researchers at the European Commission's Joint Research Center.

articles.title: Climate Change Linked to Nearly 100,000 Deaths in 2023 Heatwaves
articles.author: Agency
articles.summary: Nearly 100,000 deaths from the unprecedented heatwaves of 2023 were linked to human-induced climate change. Southern Europe experienced the highest heatwave-related mortality rates. The study highlighted that heat-related deaths were predominantly concentrated in subtropical and temperate zones of the Northern Hemisphere.

articles.title: New report finds nonprofits hit hard by Helene, federal policy changes
articles.author: Biltmore Beacon

articles.summary: Far-right parties are gaining popularity in rural Spain due to growing discontent over stringent climate regulations. New environmental policies challenge traditional farming practices and livelihoods and conservative and nationalist factions are gaining traction among voters who feel marginalized and unheard. This emerging trend was highlighted by recent elections.

articles.title: When Hot Pixels Lie: How Satellite Data Misleads Urban Heat Adaptation Efforts
articles.author: Co E-EDP
articles.summary: Satellite-derived land surface temperature (LST) data have come to dominate assessments of urban heat. This dominance is distorting global climate adaptation strategies. LST records radiative temperature of surfaces such as rooftops, pavements, and treetops, not the air temperature felt by humans. In daytime, LST can exceed SAT by up to 30°C, while at night it can fall below it.

articles.title: From the Surface to Space
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: Kevin Kilty explains the theory of response to radiative forcing from CO2 in Earth's Energy Imbalance, part II. The theory is based on an idealized, 1-D atmospheric profile with an invariant temperature gradient. It explains the enthusiasm for the radiative-vective equilibrium (RCE) model and the preponderance of feedback analysis based on it.

articles.author: Mongabay
